entries.title: Anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL) implant
entries.contributor: Jesse Vislisel, MD; Thomas A. Oetting, MS, MD

entries.title: Anterior polar cataract
entries.description: Anterior polar cataracts are congenital opacities involving the anterior capsule and subcapsular cortex. They are typically small, bilateral, symmetric, non-progressive, and not visually significant. The patient in these photographs had anterior polar cataracts that were more prominent in the left eye than the right. Only the left cataract was visually significant. OD - Slit Lamp

images.alt: Anterior Polar Catatact Slit Lamp OD
Anterior Polar Catatact Slit Lamp OS

entries.title: Anterior subcapsular cataract
entries.description: Anterior subcapsular cataracts (ASC) form after anterior lens epithelial cells become necrotic from a variety of causes including iritis, keratitis, inflammation associated with atopic dermatitis, irradiation, or electrical burns. The opacification of the lens is due to a migration of adjacent epithelial cells into the damaged area and subsequent transformation of these cells into a plaque of multiple layers of myofibroblasts. The most posterior layer of these cells remain epithelial cells and will produce a new lens capsule. Over time the myofibroblasts resolve leaving a wrinkled appearance to the lens capsule. A duplication cataract occurs when a cortical cataract develops in the same area as the ASC.

entries.title: Anterior capsular phimosis
entries.photographer: Stefani Karakas, CRA; D. Brice Critser, CRA; Antoinette Venckus, CRA
entries.description: Anterior capsular phimosis is the centripetal fibrosis and contraction of the capsulorhexis after cataract extraction. Individuals with zonular laxity are at increased risk for this condition. Mild to moderate amounts of phimosis are usually not visually significant, but severe cases may require treatment by Nd:YAG laser anterior capsulotomy. Figure1. Non-visually-significant anterior capsular phimosis after cataract surgery.Photographer: Stefani Karakas, CRA

entries.title: Chlorpromazine-induced cataract
entries.description: Stellate, anterior subcapsular cataract with granular, brown deposits along the suture lines in a patient taking chlorpromazine.

entries.title: Clear crystalline lens
entries.description: This slit lamp photo shows the clear crystalline lens of an 11-year-old child. The normal Y-sutures of the lens are faintly visible in the photograph.

images.alt: Dilated funduscopic examination showed severe, diffuse optic atrophy OD and bow-tie (band) optic atrophy OS

entries.title: Combined Anterior Polar, Posterior Subcapsular and Cortical Cataract
entries.description: This is a 40-year-old male referred for cataract evaluation. He complained of blurred vision and photosensitivity. His visual acuity is 20/400 in this eye. On exam he had a unilateral anterior polar cataract combined with central posterior subcapsular cataract with mild cortical changes. He elected to proceed with cataract extraction.

images.alt: anterior polar cataract combined with central posterior subcapsular cataract
anterior polar cataract combined with central posterior subcapsular cataract - zoomed
anterior polar cataract combined with central posterior subcapsular cataract - red

entries.title: Congenital nuclear cataract
entries.description: Congenital nuclear cataracts may involve the entire nucleus, or a portion of it as seen in this photograph. These photographs also show a mild persistent pupillary membrane which is most visible in the red reflex.

images.alt: dense fibrinous and cellular debris in the anterior chamber, which deposited on the corneal endothelium centrally and inferiorly

entries.title: Glaukomflecken and iris atrophy after acute angle closure glaucoma
entries.description: Glaukomflecken are small anterior subcapsular opacities secondary to lens epithelial necrosis resulting from acute angle closure glaucoma. These photographs from two different patients show central glaukomflecken and iris atrophy secondary to prior episodes of acute angle closure glaucoma..

entries.title: Iris incarceration in an old extracapsular wound
entries.description: This 73-year-old male had a complicated extracapsular cataract extraction 40 years ago for bilateral cataracts and was left aphakic. There is uveal tissue incarcerated in the old superior wound. This makes secondary intraocular lens placement difficult and potentially high risk.

entries.title: Morgagnian cataract
entries.description: Morgagnian cataracts are advanced cortical cataracts in which the nucleus is freely mobile within liquefied cortex. In this photo, a brunescent nucleus can be seen sunken to the bottom of the capsular bag with the white, liquefied cortex visible superiorly.

entries.title: Nuclear sclerotic cataract
entries.description: The patient was a 57-year-old man with vision loss in the right eye (OD) greater than left eye (OS) in the setting of a craniopharyngioma, which was resected 16 years prior. His visual acuity had been no light perception OD and 20/20 OS since the procedure.

images.alt: Milky appearence of Nuclear sclerotic cataract
Slit Lamp Milky appearence of Nuclear sclerotic cataract

entries.title: Ointment in anterior chamber after cataract surgery

images.alt: ointment present in the anterior chamber
enlarged ointment present in the anterior chamber

entries.title: Persistent fetal vasculature (PFV)
entries.description: Persistent fetal vasculature (PFV), previously called persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV), is a congenital defect that results when the fetal hyaloid vasculature fails to regress. The condition is almost always unilateral and associated with microphthalmia. Variable degrees of vascular remnants may remain, ranging from an isolated retrolenticular membrane to a complete stalk connecting the optic nerve to the lens as in this case. Other associated findings can include enlongated ciliary processes, prominent radial vessels or neovascularization on the iris surface, shallow anterior chamber with narrow-angle glaucoma, vitreous hemorrhage, and retinal detachment. In this photograph, a stalk can be seen emanating from the optic disc into the vitreous with tenting of the surrounding retina and dragging of the macula. The associated cataract has been removed surgically

images.alt: a stalk can be seen emanating from the optic disc into the vitreous with tenting of the surrounding retina and dragging of the macula

entries.title: Posterior Polar Cataract
entries.description: Posterior polar cataracts are a form of congenital cataract commonly associated with posterior capsule changes. They can be autosomal dominant or sporadic and are more commonly bilateral. They are rarely visually significant and are usually stable, but may progress over time. This 42-year-old patient was referred from an outside provider with complaints of blurred vision at distance and near in addition to being bothered by glare. He had 2.5 mm concentric posterior polar opacities in both eyes and elected to undergo cataract extraction

entries.title: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome
entries.description: Pseudophakic late in-the-bag lens dislocation in a patient with pseudoexfoliation glaucoma. In this particular case, refixation or lens exchange is more complicated and challenging in the setting of trabeculectomy bleb is shown.

entries.title: Siderosis bulbi
entries.contributor: Joanna IM. Silverman, MD; Timothy M. Boyce, MD
entries.description: February 13, 2023 These external photographs demonstrate an acquired hyperchromic heterochromia due to a traumatic intraocular iron foreign body in the right eye. Chronic deposition of iron within the iris stroma resulted in the gradual darkening of the native light-colored iris. Figure 1.

rust-colored anterior subcapsular deposits siderosis bulbi slit lamp

entries.title: Aftercataract (Elschnig's pearls)
entries.description: September 18, 2023 Our patient is a 47-year-old male with a history of myotonic muscular dystrophy and bilateral cataract extraction with implantation of intraocular lens. This was complicated by the development of bilateral dense posterior capsular opacities that were resistant to YAG capsulotomy (attempted twice in the right eye prior to this presentation). He presented with 2 days of “a line in my vision that changes angles when I move my head.” During the slit lamp exam, he was noted to have a large Elschnig pearl suspended in his central visual axis which swung with his eye movements as demonstrated in the video above. Hanging Elschnig Pearl

entries.title: Phacomorphic Angle Closure and Anterior Lens Dislocation due to Repeated Blunt Trauma
entries.contributor: Lauren E. Hock, MD and A. Tim Johnson, MD, PhD
entries.description: Lensectomy is the definitive treatment for both phacomorphic angle closure and pupillary block secondary to lens dislocation. Slit lamp photograph of the right eye shows 3+ diffuse injection with the crystalline lens filling the anterior chamber, lenticulocorneal touch, stromal edema, 360 degree iridocorneal touch, and posterior capsule opacification. Intraocular pressure was 40 mmHg at presentation.

images.alt: slit lamp photo of the right eye
Anterior segment optical coherence tomography (AS-OCT) of the left eye

entries.title: Artisan(claw) intraocular lens
entries.contributor: Dr. Swaranjit Singh Bhatti, Bhatti Eye Clinic

images.alt: slit lamp photo of the right eye

entries.title: Brunescent cataract
entries.description: Posted: October 21, 2013 Brunescent cataracts are very advanced nuclear cataracts that have become brown and opaque.

entries.title: Capsular folds secondary to posterior capsule opacification
entries.description: Posted: July 31, 2013 This patient has an iris-sutured posterior-chamber intraocular lens, placed secondary to zonular weakness. This image, taken one month after the procedure, shows prominent capsular phimosis with radial folds and central 2-3+ capsular opacification. This was treated using a Nd:YAG laser posterior capsulotomy. Revised June 6, 2016, with thanks to Dr. Luis Alberto Real, Cirujano Oftalmólogo, Especializado en la Clínica Barraquer, Sub-especializado en el IOBA, Valladolid, España

entries.title: Christmas Tree Cataract
entries.contributor: Elizabeth Gauger, MD and Anna Kitzmann, MD
entries.description: Category(ies): Cataract Posted: July 31, 2013 Christmas tree decoration cataract or polychromatic cataract

images.alt: Christmas tree decoration cataract or polychromatic cataract

entries.title: Temporal iris and lens coloboma associated with cataract
entries.description: This is unusual as colobomas are typically inferonasal, where the optic fissure fails to close completely during development.

images.alt: close-up of coloboma with a cataract
ongenital cataract follows the embryonic suture lines of the lens

entries.title: Congenital lamellar / zonular cataract in a child
Coppock Cataract
entries.description: This is called a "Coppock cataract," also known as a "central pulverulent cataract." It refers to a pulverulent disc-like opactiy involving the embryonal and fetal nucleus with many tiny white dots in the lamellar portion of the lens. It is usually bilateral and dominantly inherited.

entries.title: Decentered posterior chamber intraocular lens
entries.description: This posterior chamber intraocular lens became inferiorly decentered within the capsular bag. It was later surgically repositioned successfully.

images.alt: posterior chamber intraocular lens became inferiorly decentered within the capsular bag
alternative view posterior chamber intraocular lens became inferiorly decentered within the capsular bag

entries.title: Epicapsular stars and persistent pupillary membrane
Hyphema following aborted iStent procedure
entries.contributor: Austin R. Fox, MD, and Michael Griess, MD
entries.description: External photograph of the left eye shows a contracting post-operative hyphema two weeks after an iStent® trabecular micro-bypass procedure. The surgery had been aborted due to development of a hyphema and poor view. A hyphema is a rare complication during iStent insertion but has been reported in several publications [1-7]. However, microhyphemas observed on gonioscopy after the iStent procedure are more commonly seen.

images.alt: contracting post-operative hyphema two weeks after an iStent

entries.title: Iridodialysis and traumatic cataract after firecracker injury
entries.description: Iridodialysis is the result of a tear in the iris root. It may be repaired surgically or with cosmetic contact lenses if large or symptomatic. This cataract's rosette pattern is classically seen after contusion injuries. It is due to separation of lens fibers around lens sutures

entries.title: Kayser-Fleischer Ring in Wilson's Disease
entries.description: Figure 1a. Slit lamp photographs of sunflower cataracts of the right eye. Note the ring-shaped, anterior capsular opacities that resemble a "sunflower," a finding that is classically associated with Wilson's Disease.

images.alt: Slit lamp photographs of sunflower cataracts of the right eye
Slit lamp photographs of sunflower cataracts of the left eye

Slit lamp photographs of a Kayser-Fleischer ring directprofile
S posterior corneal reflex loses the prominent golden/copper hue centrally
Slit lamp gonioscopy photographs of a Kayser-Fleischer ring

entries.title: Mature Cataract
entries.description: This patient with mature cataract (nuclear sclerotic and cortical changes) had only bare light perception vision.

images.alt: this elderly female presented with a mature cataract in the right eye

entries.title: Mature cortical cataract
entries.description: In a mature cortical cataract, also known as a "white cataract," the entire lens cortex has become opacified. Water clefts are visible as less opaque radial wedges within the lens. These lenses can swell as a result of increased water uptake, at which point they are called intumescent cataracts.

entries.title: Mittendorf dot
entries.description: A Mittendorf dot is a small, circular opacity on the posterior lens capsule, classically nasal in location, which represents the anterior attachment of the hyaloid artery. The hyaloid artery is present during gestation and typically regresses completely. Failure to do so can lead to benign findings, such as a Mittendorf dot or a Bergmeister's papilla, or pathologic changes as seen in persistent fetal vasculature syndrome.

entries.title: Morgagnian cataract with absent cortex
entries.contributor: Christopher A. Kirkpatrick, MD and Anna Kitzmann, MD
entries.description: A Morgagnian cataract is a hypermature cataract in which there is typically liquefaction of the lens cortex with dense sclerosis of the nucleus. This presentation is typical for the brunescent lens nucleus that is inferiorly displaced within the capsule, but atypical in that there is no lens cortex remaining, the previously liquified cortex has migrated through the intact capsule, leaving only a sunken, hard nucleus in an empty capsular bag

entries.title: Ocular Syphilis Presenting with Posterior Subcapsular Cataract
entries.description: A 50-year-old male presented with 10 days of progressive vision loss in the left eye (OS) as well as fevers, fatigue, and unintentional weight loss. Visual acuity was hand motion OS. Slitlamp examination showed 1+ anterior vitreous cells. On funduscopy, he had severe optic disc edema with 360 degrees of peripapillary cotton wool spots and nerve fiber layer hemorrhages, along with a serous retinal detachment with peripapillary yellowish inflammation in the outer retina around the disc (A). He was found to have active syphilis with AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome). He was treated with penicillin at that time and anti-retroviral therapy was ultimately initiated by the infectious diseases service

images.alt: Syphilis Presenting with Posterior Subcapsular Cataract
fundus photos of syphilis with AIDS
Diffuse illumination slit lamp photograph of an oil-droplet cataract showing central nuclear yellow opacity of the lens with dark clearing surrounding the oil-droplet.

Optical section slit lamp photograph of the right eye showing a 3+ oil-droplet cataract with the central yellow opacified nucleus surrounded by an area of dark clearing followed by the cortical and capsular layers anteriorly.

entries.title: Persistent pupillary membranes (1)
entries.description: Persistent pupillary membranes are the result of remnants of the tunica vasculosa lentis, a vascular network that surround the lens during embryogenesis. They can vary in presentation from a few fine iris strands bridging the pupil to intricate webs with attachments to the lens. Intricate webs with attachments to the lens

images.alt: Related Atals Entry: Persistent Pupillary Membrane
Related Atals Entry: Persistent Pupillary Membrane

entries.title: Persistent Pupillary Membrane (2)
entries.description: Persistent pupillary membrane is an embryologic remnant of the tunica vasculosa lentis, the vascular bed that surrounded the lens during fetal development. This is an atypical presentation with only one single, fine iris strand that has fibrosed to the anterior lens capsule.

images.alt: external photo showing Persistent pupillary membrane is an embryologic remnant of the tunica vasculosa lentis
Related Atlas Entry: Persistent pupillary membrane
Related Atlas Entry: Persistent pupillary membrane

entries.title: Posterior capsular opacity (PCO) following cataract surgery

images.alt: Slit lamp showing PCIOL with a membrane forming behind lens
Slit lamp showing PCIOL with a membrane forming behind lens
Slit lamp photo of left eye demonstrating superior posterior capsular opacification of the intraocular lens implant with broad-beam illumination.
Slit lamp photo of left eye intraocular lens implant demonstrating retroillumination of superior posterior capsular opacification (PCO). Note the PCO originates along the lens-haptic junction.

entries.title: Posterior subcapsular cataract
entries.description: This patient is a diabetic male whose vision decreased dramatically over the course of about a month. Glare was a significant complaint.

entries.title: Posterior subcapsular cataract
entries.description: A 53-year-old female with a past medical history of Type 1 diabetes mellitus presented for blurry vision in her left eye. On exam, she was noted to have granular lenticular opacities adjacent to the posterior capsule of the natural crystalline lens in the right eye. A diagnosis of posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC) was made. Factors such as diabetes mellitus, chlorpromazine use, or corticosteroids increase the risk of PSC formation. [1] In comparison to other cataract types, glare and decreased near acuity may be more common presenting symptoms. These types of cataracts are best viewed with slit lamp biomicroscopy retroillumination; care should be taken to achieve line of focus on the posterior capsule, or the cataract can be readily missed

images.alt: Thin fibrotic membrane on the posterior lens capsule.
Thin fibrotic membrane on the posterior lens capsule.
Thin fibrotic membrane on the posterior lens capsule.
Thin fibrotic membrane on the posterior lens capsule.
Patient with pseudoexfoliation syndrome who had a cataract extraction and placement of an intraocular lens. Many years later

entries.title: Silicone oil droplet on intraocular lens (IOL)
entries.contributor: Christopher Kirkpatrick, MD and Anna Kitzmann, MD
entries.description: Silicone oil is a commonly used material in retina surgery, typically vitrectomy; it’s adherence to silicone IOLs is a widely recognized phenomenon and use of a silicone IOL is contraindicated in patients that have had or are at high risk of needing a vitrectomy. Silicone oil on an IOL is seen as variable sized droplets that are adherent to the surface of the IOL. These can be visually significant to varying degrees based on size and location of the droplets. The picture represents a patient who underwent cataract surgery with placement of a 3-piece silicone IOL about 3 years prior to presenting with a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment requiring pars plana vitrectomy with silicone oil placement and scleral buckle. He later presented with this large silicone oil droplet adherent to the posterior surface of his IOL. He went on to have an IOL exchange with silicone oil removal

entries.title: Traumatic aniridia and cataract
entries.description: This patient was referred to another ophthalmologist for cataract extraction and insertion of a pupillary prosthesis.

entries.title: Traumatic rosette cataract
entries.contributor: Dr. Swaranjit Singh Bhatti, Bhatti Eye Clinic
entries.description: This is a traumatic rosette cataract seen in fundal retroillumination (against the fundal red glow) on the slit lamp.The leaf like "rosette" pattern is pathognomonic of a traumatic cataract and the clear zone outside the affect lens lamellae indicate that the trauma occurred several years before as clear lens fibres have been laid down in the periphery subsequently.

images.alt: traumatic rosette cataract seen in fundal retroillumination
Dilated funduscopic examination showed severe, diffuse optic atrophy OD and bow-tie (band) optic atrophy OS

entries.title: "Y-suture" Cataract
entries.description: This is a 46-year-old male with a promient Y-suture cataract. This is a congenital lens opacity that occurs at the location of closure of the fetal lenticular nucleus. The anterior sutures are in the shape of a Y and the posterior sutures are an inverted Y. These are rarely visually signficant

images.alt: promient Y-suture cataract seen in the middle of the eye
zonules can be readily visualized in the dilated pupil of this patient with Marfan's syndrome

entries.title: Anterior polar cataract
entries.contributor: Andrew Doan, MD, PhD, Jordan Graff, MD, William Charles Caccamise, Sr, MD

entries.title: Cataract with refractile bodies
entries.contributor: Andrew Doan, MD, PhD and Jordan Graff, MD

entries.title: Cerulean Cataract
entries.description: Cerulean cataracts are composed of small bluish dot-like opacities in the peripheral lens cortex. They usually do not cause visual symptoms. This patient also has a dense central posterior subcapsular cataract which was visually significant.

images.alt: Cerulean cataract looking imagine the blue color on tarnished copper

entries.title: Retained Lens Fragment
entries.description: Posted: 06/03/2024 A 72-year-old man presented one week after uncomplicated cataract surgery for progressive photophobia and blurry vision in the surgical eye. On exam, there was a retained lens fragment in the anterior chamber. Small pieces of nuclear or cortical lens material can sometimes be hidden in the ciliary sulcus at the end of cataract surgery. Patients present with an inflammatory picture. Often times cortical material can be observed and treated medically with anti-inflammatory topical treatment. Nuclear material, as in this case, however, often requires surgical intervention with removal of the lenticular remnant

entries.title: Iris coloboma
entries.description: Posted: 06/04/2024 A 20-year-old man presented for routine follow up of congenital nystagmus. Anterior segment examination revealed an iris coloboma in both eyes. In the right eye, there was concomitant congenital cataract. Colobomas are developmental defects that result from incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure. Colobomas can involve the iris, ciliary body, choroid, retina, and optic nerve. Colobomas are located in the inferonasal quadrant

entries.title: Late Capsular Block with Posterior Capsular Fibrosis
entries.description: Posted: 06/04/2024 A 44-year-old pseudophakic female presented with progressive worsening vision after uncomplicated cataract surgery 8 years prior. The patient has a history of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with prior vitrectomy and developed cataracts early. On exam, there were thick posterior capsular opacities with a capsular block appearance and fluid noted beyond the intraocular lens.

entries.title: Opacification of Hydrophilic Intraocular Lens
entries.description: Posted: 06/27/2024 A 64-year-old man with a history of bilateral pseudophakia and partial-thickness corneal transplantation in both eyes presented for progressive vision loss in the left eye. The patient underwent uncomplicated cataract surgery several years ago and then subsequently, more recently, had uncomplicated Descemet membrane endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK) for Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy. On exam, there was a centered intraocular lens in the capsular bag. The intraocular lens had a stippled central opacification extending through the visual axis on the anterior lens surface. On further investigation, the intraocular lens was confirmed to be an Akreos MI60 hydrophilic lens. It was suspected that the lens had opacified after exposure to intraocular gas following DMEK surgery

entries.title: Vitreous strand to paracentesis causing subtle peaked pupil early in case
entries.description: Posted: 08/22/2024 Here is an example of a subtle peaked pupil early during cataract surgery. The patient has an essentially invisible strand ov vitreous that is going to the paracentesis from a peripheral point which is causing peaking of the pupil. Vitreous prolapse that extends to a paracentesis such as in this case can cause peaking of the pupil. In this case the vitreous presented early in the case making the surgery very difficult. The caractous lens was removed by converting to an ECCE supplemented with an anterior vittectomy.

images.alt: Vitreous prolapse that extends to a paracentesis such as in this case can cause peaking of the pupil.  In this case the vitreous presented early in the case making the surgery very difficult.   The caractous lens was removed by converting to an ECCE supplemented with an anterior vittectomy.

entries.title: Calcific Deposits on an Intraocular Lens
entries.contributor: Christian A. Mays, MD; Erin A. Boese, MD
entries.description: Posted: 01/10/2025 A 72-year-old woman presented with widely fluctuating visual acuity following an uncomplicated phacoemulsification combined with 360° gonioscopy-assisted transluminal trabeculotomy (GATT). Post-operatively, her course was notable for a 2.5mm hyphema, which cleared within a week. On follow-up examination at three months, she had a persistent intracapsular hemorrhage with a superficial layer of dehemoglobinized blood in her right eye (Figure 1A). She underwent a neodymium-aluminum-garnet (Nd:YAG) capsulotomy with immediate clearance of the blood (Figure 1B). Two weeks following the capsulotomy, she had complete resolution of her fluctuating visual acuity

images.alt: A 72-year-old woman presented with widely fluctuating visual acuity following an uncomplicated phacoemulsification combined with 360° gonioscopy-assisted transluminal trabeculotomy (GATT). Post-operatively, her course was notable for a 2.5mm hyphema, which cleared within a week. On follow-up examination at three months, she had a persistent intracapsular hemorrhage with a superficial layer of dehemoglobinized blood in her right eye (Figure 1A). She underwent a neodymium-aluminum-garnet (Nd:YAG) capsulotomy with immediate clearance of the blood (Figure 1B).

entries.title: Layered intracapsular hemorrhage following phacoemulsification GATT
entries.contributor: Peter H. Sanchez MD; Bilal Ahmed MD; Thomas Oetting MD;
entries.description: Posted: 12/09/2024 A 74-year-old female with history of proliferative diabetic retinopathy in both eyes (OU), lamellar hole in the left eye (OS), POAG status post Ahmed tube in the right eye (OD), full thickness macular hole OD status post vitrectomy, and cataract extraction with implantation of AMO 9002, 3-piece silicone intraocular lenses OU 15 years ago was referred for a several month history of blurry and decreased vision OS. She had already undergone YAG-laser capsulotomy OS by an outside provider without improvement in her visual acuity. On presentation, her vision was 20/200 OS. Her exam was notable for granular, white deposits on the posterior surface of the lens OS. She had already undergone explantation of the OD silicone lens for a similar process. She was consented for intraocular lens exchange OS with a MA50BM lens

images.alt: Retroillumation of calcium deposits on a 3-piece silicone intraocular lens.
Broad beam illumination of calcium deposits on the posterior surface of a 3-piece silicone intraocular lens.

entries.title: Posterior Polar Cataract with Traumatic Posterior Capsule Rupture
entries.contributor: Nicolas J Heckenlaible MD; Patrick J Donegan MD; Lindsay M De Andrade MD
entries.description: Posted: 06/20/2025 A 16-year-old male with a known history of bilateral posterior polar cataracts and baseline visual acuity of 20/20-1 without correction in each eye sustained a traumatic impact to the right eye from a thrown water bottle. On initial evaluation after trauma, his visual acuity was decreased to 20/200 without correction (20/30-2 with pinhole). Anterior segment exam revealed multiple corneal abrasions in the visual axis of the right eye but was otherwise unremarkable. He was prescribed erythromycin ointment and advised to return in 1 week. He was lost to follow up and returned six months later with continued decrease in vision in his right eye. At this time, his visual acuity was 20/200 without correction (20/60 with pinhole)

images.alt: Diffuse illumination slit lamp photograph of a posterior polar cataract with posterior capsular rupture.
Slit lamp photograph showing retro-illumination of a posterior polar cataract with posterior capsular rupture.

entries.title: Unique Electric Cataract
entries.contributor: Thomas D. Meram, MD; Ryan J. Diel, MD
entries.photographer: Meghan C. Menzel, CRA; Michael T. Edrington, CRA
entries.description: Posted: 06/02/2025 Slit lamp photos of a 32-year-old male with cataracts sustained after 270-volt electrocution injury. The cataracts appeared as a ring within the lens nucleus in a circumferential pattern following the natural lens architecture. Patient had no subjective visual symptoms. Appearance of the cataracts was stable at 2 days and 6 months post injury. The patient has no known history of congenital cataracts; however, a baseline exam was not available. Slit lamp photo at two days post injury

images.alt: Slit lamp photo at two days post injury.
Slit lamp photo at six months post injury.

entries.title: Subluxated posterior chamber intraocular lens implant
entries.contributor: Noor-Us-Sabah Ahmad, MD; Chad Y. Lewis, MD, MPH; Thomas A. Oetting, MS, MD
entries.description: Posted: 06/26/2025 A 70-year-old man presented to the clinic 2 years after right-sided cataract extraction with a posterior chamber intra-ocular lens (PCIOL) implant performed at an outside hospital. He reported blurriness as well as seeing a "half-moon shadow" in his right eye vision. Slit lamp examination of his right eye showed inferonasal subluxation of his PCIOL along with 2+ posterior capsular opacification and cortical material within the capsular bag. He was taken to the OR for an IOL exchange procedure. Intra-operatively, a posterior capsular tear was encountered which was complicated by the IOL protruding out of the tear and vitreous prolapse. He underwent IOL explantation and anterior vitrectomy followed by placement of a new IOL in the sulcus with capture by the anterior capsule

images.alt: Retroillumination on slit lamp examination showed inferonasal subluxation of PCIOL along with 2+ posterior capsular opacification
Diffuse illumination on slit lamp examination showed inferonasal subluxation of PCIOL

entries.contributor: Cy Lewis, MD; Bilal Ahmed, MD; Marc Toeteberg-Harms, MD;
entries.description: Posted: 06/17/2025 Acute onset white cataract with cortical material in the anterior chamber two weeks after a corneal laceration with anterior capsule violation Capsular violation following a corneal laceration.
